uniqueIssues.issue: A heading element (h3) is being used for decorative text. Misusing headings for non-structural content can confuse assistive technology users who rely on heading navigation.
uniqueIssues.suggestedFix:
If this text is purely decorative, use a non-heading element and hide it from assistive technologies:

Welcome to Luxury

. If it conveys structure, choose the correct heading level according to the page hierarchy (e.g.,

...).

uniqueIssues.issue: The main content of the page is not contained within a <main> landmark. Without a main region (or another mechanism), keyboard and screen reader users lack a reliable way to bypass repeated content like the header.
uniqueIssues.suggestedFix:
Introduce a
landmark around the primary content. For example:

Welcome to Luxury

Optionally pair this with a skip link that targets #main-content.

uniqueIssues.issue: Text input lacks an associated label; relying on placeholder alone does not meet the requirement for clear labels.
uniqueIssues.suggestedFix: Provide a programmatically associated label. For example: <label htmlFor="firstName">First Name</label><input id="firstName" type="text" name="firstName" placeholder="First Name" />

uniqueIssues.issue: Text input lacks an associated label; relying on placeholder alone does not meet the requirement for clear labels.
uniqueIssues.suggestedFix: Provide a programmatically associated label. For example: <label htmlFor="lastName">Last Name</label><input id="lastName" type="text" name="lastName" placeholder="Last Name" />

uniqueIssues.issue: Email input lacks an associated label; placeholder text is not an adequate substitute.
uniqueIssues.suggestedFix: Provide a programmatically associated label. For example: <label htmlFor="email">Email Address</label><input id="email" type="email" name="email" placeholder="Email Address" />

uniqueIssues.issue: Telephone input lacks an associated label; placeholder text is not an adequate substitute.
uniqueIssues.suggestedFix: Provide a programmatically associated label. For example: <label htmlFor="phone">Phone Number</label><input id="phone" type="tel" name="phone" placeholder="Phone Number" />

uniqueIssues.issue: Textarea lacks an associated label; placeholder text is not an adequate substitute.
uniqueIssues.suggestedFix: Provide a programmatically associated label. For example: <label htmlFor="message">Your Message</label><textarea id="message" name="message" rows="5" placeholder="Your Message"></textarea>

uniqueIssues.issue: Clickable div used as a button is not keyboard-operable by default (not focusable and lacks key handlers).
uniqueIssues.suggestedFix: Use a native button within a form for full keyboard and AT support: <form onSubmit={handleSubmit}>...<button type="submit" className="submit-btn">Submit</button></form>. If a non-button is kept, add role="button", tabIndex={0}, and handle Enter/Space via onKeyDown.

uniqueIssues.issue: Form controls are not contained within a semantic <form> element, reducing programmatic relationships and native submit behavior (e.g., Enter key to submit).
uniqueIssues.suggestedFix: Wrap the inputs and submit control in a <form> with an onSubmit handler: <form className="contact-form" onSubmit={handleSubmit}>...</form> and use a <button type="submit">.

uniqueIssues.issue: Common input purpose is not programmatically identifiable; missing appropriate autocomplete token.
uniqueIssues.suggestedFix: Add an appropriate autocomplete attribute: <input id="firstName" type="text" name="firstName" autocomplete="given-name" placeholder="First Name" />

uniqueIssues.issue: Common input purpose is not programmatically identifiable; missing appropriate autocomplete token.
uniqueIssues.suggestedFix: Add an appropriate autocomplete attribute: <input id="lastName" type="text" name="lastName" autocomplete="family-name" placeholder="Last Name" />

uniqueIssues.issue: Common input purpose is not programmatically identifiable; missing appropriate autocomplete token.
uniqueIssues.suggestedFix: Add an appropriate autocomplete attribute: <input id="email" type="email" name="email" autocomplete="email" placeholder="Email Address" />

uniqueIssues.issue: Common input purpose is not programmatically identifiable; missing appropriate autocomplete token.
uniqueIssues.suggestedFix: Add an appropriate autocomplete attribute: <input id="phone" type="tel" name="phone" autocomplete="tel" placeholder="Phone Number" />

uniqueIssues.issue: Availability is conveyed by color alone (status dot) with no textual indicator, which is not accessible to users who cannot perceive color.
uniqueIssues.suggestedFix: Include a text label for the status in addition to the dot and hide the dot from assistive tech, e.g.: {room.available ? 'Available' : 'Booked'}

uniqueIssues.issue: Non-semantic element used as a link. A span styled to look interactive lacks an accessible role/name and is not keyboard accessible.
uniqueIssues.suggestedFix: Use a semantic link/button with an accessible name, e.g.: Read more about {room.name} // or if it triggers an action

uniqueIssues.issue: Ambiguous link/control text. 'Read More' does not clearly indicate purpose or destination.
uniqueIssues.suggestedFix: Make the label specific, e.g.: Read more about {room.name}.

uniqueIssues.issue: Low contrast text. Gold (#c9a962) on a very light background (#faf9f7) is approximately 2.0:1, below the 4.5:1 minimum for normal text.
uniqueIssues.suggestedFix: Use a darker text color that achieves at least 4.5:1 on #faf9f7 (e.g., color: #6b4e00) or increase size/weight to meet large text criterion. Example: .contact-info .section-label { color: #6b4e00; }

uniqueIssues.issue: Low contrast text. Gold (#c9a962) used for small labels is approximately 2.0:1 on a light background, below the 4.5:1 minimum for normal text.
uniqueIssues.suggestedFix: Choose a darker color for labels (e.g., #6b4e00) or provide a darker background behind the label to achieve ≥4.5:1. Example: .contact-label { color: #6b4e00; }

uniqueIssues.issue: Insufficient non-text contrast for input boundaries. The light gray border (#e5e5e5) against a very light background (~#faf9f7) has ~1.2:1 contrast, below the 3:1 required for UI component boundaries.
uniqueIssues.suggestedFix: Use a darker border (≥3:1 against surrounding background), increase thickness, or provide a contrasting fill. Example: .contact-form input, .contact-form textarea { border: 1px solid #767676; }

uniqueIssues.issue: Focus state for inputs uses gold (#c9a962) which contrasts ~2.0:1 against a very light background, below the 3:1 required for visible UI component indicators.
uniqueIssues.suggestedFix: Provide a higher-contrast focus indicator (e.g., 2px outline or border) that meets ≥3:1. Example: .contact-form input:focus-visible, .contact-form textarea:focus-visible { outline: 2px solid #005fcc; outline-offset: 2px; }

uniqueIssues.issue: White button text on the gold gradient background (#c9a962–#b8944f) yields ~2.1–2.9:1 contrast, below the 4.5:1 minimum for normal text.
uniqueIssues.suggestedFix: Either darken the gradient substantially or use a dark text color. Example: .submit-btn { background: linear-gradient(135deg, #6b4e00 0%, #614400 100%); color: #1a1a1a; }

uniqueIssues.issue: Hover state is styled but there is no corresponding visible keyboard focus style, which can make focus difficult to see for keyboard users.
uniqueIssues.suggestedFix: Add a :focus-visible style that provides a clear focus indicator. Example: .submit-btn:focus-visible { outline: 2px solid #005fcc; outline-offset: 2px; }

uniqueIssues.issue: Low contrast on link hover. Gold (#c9a962) on a white background is ~2.1:1, below the 4.5:1 minimum for normal text.
uniqueIssues.suggestedFix: Use a hover color that maintains ≥4.5:1 contrast (e.g., #6b4e00), or add a contrasting background highlight. Example: .link-list a:hover { color: #6b4e00; }

uniqueIssues.issue: Hover state is styled but there is no corresponding :focus-visible style for keyboard users, reducing focus visibility.
uniqueIssues.suggestedFix: Mirror hover styles for focus. Example: .link-list a:focus-visible { color: #6b4e00; outline: 2px solid #005fcc; outline-offset: 2px; }

uniqueIssues.issue: Hover state is styled but there is no :focus-visible state, making keyboard focus on social icons potentially invisible.
uniqueIssues.suggestedFix: Provide a visible focus style. Example: .social-icon:focus-visible { outline: 2px solid #005fcc; outline-offset: 3px; opacity: 1; }

uniqueIssues.issue: Low contrast on navigation item hover. Gold (#c9a962) over a light header background (~white) is ~2.1:1, below the 4.5:1 minimum for normal text.
uniqueIssues.suggestedFix: Use a darker hover color that maintains ≥4.5:1 contrast (e.g., #6b4e00) or add a contrasting background/underline on hover. Example: .nav-item:hover { color: #6b4e00; }

uniqueIssues.issue: White button text on the gold gradient background (#c9a962–#b8944f) yields ~2.1–2.9:1 contrast, below the 4.5:1 minimum for normal text.
uniqueIssues.suggestedFix: Use a darker text color or darken the gradient. Example: .book-btn { background: linear-gradient(135deg, #6b4e00 0%, #614400 100%); color: #1a1a1a; }

uniqueIssues.issue: Hover state is styled but no :focus-visible style is provided, which can make keyboard focus hard to detect.
uniqueIssues.suggestedFix: Add a clear focus style. Example: .book-btn:focus-visible { outline: 2px solid #005fcc; outline-offset: 2px; }

uniqueIssues.issue: Hover state is styled but there is no corresponding visible focus style for keyboard users.
uniqueIssues.suggestedFix: Mirror hover styles for focus and add a clear focus indicator. Example: .nav-item:focus-visible { color: #6b4e00; outline: 2px solid #005fcc; outline-offset: 2px; }

uniqueIssues.issue: Low text contrast: Gold text (#c9a962) on a white background does not meet the minimum 4.5:1 contrast ratio for normal text. This affects readability of table values in non-header columns.
Links are not visually distinguishable from surrounding text. Removing underlines combined with inherited color makes links rely on color (or no difference) alone to convey link state.

Links inherit the surrounding text color, removing a key differentiator. Combined with no underline, this causes links to be indistinguishable from body text, relying on color alone (or no difference) to indicate link status.
Low text contrast: Gold text (#c9a962) on the light section background (#faf9f7) does not meet the minimum 4.5:1 contrast ratio for normal text (used for the section label).
Low text contrast: Price text (#c9a962) on white background does not meet contrast requirements. Even as large text (24px), it must meet at least 3:1, which this color does not.
Low text contrast: Secondary price period text (#999999) on white background does not meet the 4.5:1 ratio for normal text (14px).
Low text contrast on hover: Changing link text to #c9a962 on a white background reduces contrast below the required ratio, making the hovered state less readable.
Global removal of focus outlines hides focus indicators for all interactive elements, making keyboard navigation difficult to track.
Links inherit the same color as surrounding text, making them indistinguishable in running text.
Removing link underlines removes a key non-color cue that indicates links, making them hard to detect.
The low-contrast text color (#cccccc) against white background (~2.2:1) fails minimum text contrast requirements.
Status indicator relies on color alone (green dot) to convey availability, which is not accessible for users who cannot perceive color differences.
uniqueIssues.suggestedFix: Do not rely on color alone. Add a text label (e.g., "Available") adjacent to the dot, or use an icon/shape difference in addition to color. Ensure the label is visible and programmatically associated (e.g., include text in the DOM, not only via CSS pseudo-elements).

uniqueIssues.issue: Status indicator relies on color alone (red dot) to convey a "booked" state, which is not accessible for users who cannot perceive color differences.
uniqueIssues.suggestedFix: Include a non-color cue such as a text label (e.g., "Booked") next to the dot or a distinct icon/shape. Ensure the label is present in the DOM for assistive technologies.

uniqueIssues.issue: Form field borders are very low contrast against the white background, making input boundaries hard to discern.
White button text on the gold gradient background is unlikely to meet the 4.5:1 contrast ratio for normal-size text.
Gold text on a white (or light) background has insufficient contrast for normal text in outline buttons.
On hover, outline buttons switch to white text on a gold background, which may not meet the 4.5:1 contrast ratio.

complianceIssues.suggestedFix: Use a darker border (≥3:1 against surrounding background), increase thickness, or provide a contrasting fill. Example: .contact-form input, .contact-form textarea { border: 1px solid #767676; }

complianceIssues.issue: Focus state for inputs uses gold (#c9a962) which contrasts ~2.0:1 against a very light background, below the 3:1 required for visible UI component indicators.
complianceIssues.suggestedFix: Provide a higher-contrast focus indicator (e.g., 2px outline or border) that meets ≥3:1. Example: .contact-form input:focus-visible, .contact-form textarea:focus-visible { outline: 2px solid #005fcc; outline-offset: 2px; }

complianceIssues.issue: White button text on the gold gradient background (#c9a962–#b8944f) yields ~2.1–2.9:1 contrast, below the 4.5:1 minimum for normal text.
complianceIssues.suggestedFix: Either darken the gradient substantially or use a dark text color. Example: .submit-btn { background: linear-gradient(135deg, #6b4e00 0%, #614400 100%); color: #1a1a1a; }

complianceIssues.issue: Hover state is styled but there is no corresponding visible keyboard focus style, which can make focus difficult to see for keyboard users.
complianceIssues.suggestedFix: Add a :focus-visible style that provides a clear focus indicator. Example: .submit-btn:focus-visible { outline: 2px solid #005fcc; outline-offset: 2px; }

complianceIssues.issue: Low contrast on link hover. Gold (#c9a962) on a white background is ~2.1:1, below the 4.5:1 minimum for normal text.
complianceIssues.suggestedFix: Use a hover color that maintains ≥4.5:1 contrast (e.g., #6b4e00), or add a contrasting background highlight. Example: .link-list a:hover { color: #6b4e00; }

complianceIssues.issue: Hover state is styled but there is no corresponding :focus-visible style for keyboard users, reducing focus visibility.
complianceIssues.suggestedFix: Mirror hover styles for focus. Example: .link-list a:focus-visible { color: #6b4e00; outline: 2px solid #005fcc; outline-offset: 2px; }

complianceIssues.issue: Hover state is styled but there is no :focus-visible state, making keyboard focus on social icons potentially invisible.
complianceIssues.suggestedFix: Provide a visible focus style. Example: .social-icon:focus-visible { outline: 2px solid #005fcc; outline-offset: 3px; opacity: 1; }

complianceIssues.issue: Low contrast on navigation item hover. Gold (#c9a962) over a light header background (~white) is ~2.1:1, below the 4.5:1 minimum for normal text.
complianceIssues.suggestedFix: Use a darker hover color that maintains ≥4.5:1 contrast (e.g., #6b4e00) or add a contrasting background/underline on hover. Example: .nav-item:hover { color: #6b4e00; }

complianceIssues.issue: White button text on the gold gradient background (#c9a962–#b8944f) yields ~2.1–2.9:1 contrast, below the 4.5:1 minimum for normal text.
complianceIssues.suggestedFix: Use a darker text color or darken the gradient. Example: .book-btn { background: linear-gradient(135deg, #6b4e00 0%, #614400 100%); color: #1a1a1a; }

complianceIssues.issue: Hover state is styled but no :focus-visible style is provided, which can make keyboard focus hard to detect.
complianceIssues.suggestedFix: Add a clear focus style. Example: .book-btn:focus-visible { outline: 2px solid #005fcc; outline-offset: 2px; }

complianceIssues.issue: Hover state is styled but there is no corresponding visible focus style for keyboard users.
complianceIssues.suggestedFix: Mirror hover styles for focus and add a clear focus indicator. Example: .nav-item:focus-visible { color: #6b4e00; outline: 2px solid #005fcc; outline-offset: 2px; }

complianceIssues.issue: Low text contrast: Gold text (#c9a962) on a white background does not meet the minimum 4.5:1 contrast ratio for normal text. This affects readability of table values in non-header columns.
Links are not visually distinguishable from surrounding text. Removing underlines combined with inherited color makes links rely on color (or no difference) alone to convey link state.

Links inherit the surrounding text color, removing a key differentiator. Combined with no underline, this causes links to be indistinguishable from body text, relying on color alone (or no difference) to indicate link status.
Low text contrast: Gold text (#c9a962) on the light section background (#faf9f7) does not meet the minimum 4.5:1 contrast ratio for normal text (used for the section label).
Low text contrast: Price text (#c9a962) on white background does not meet contrast requirements. Even as large text (24px), it must meet at least 3:1, which this color does not.
Low text contrast: Secondary price period text (#999999) on white background does not meet the 4.5:1 ratio for normal text (14px).
Low text contrast on hover: Changing link text to #c9a962 on a white background reduces contrast below the required ratio, making the hovered state less readable.
Global removal of focus outlines hides focus indicators for all interactive elements, making keyboard navigation difficult to track.
Links inherit the same color as surrounding text, making them indistinguishable in running text.
Removing link underlines removes a key non-color cue that indicates links, making them hard to detect.
The low-contrast text color (#cccccc) against white background (~2.2:1) fails minimum text contrast requirements.
Status indicator relies on color alone (green dot) to convey availability, which is not accessible for users who cannot perceive color differences.
complianceIssues.suggestedFix: Do not rely on color alone. Add a text label (e.g., "Available") adjacent to the dot, or use an icon/shape difference in addition to color. Ensure the label is visible and programmatically associated (e.g., include text in the DOM, not only via CSS pseudo-elements).

complianceIssues.issue: Status indicator relies on color alone (red dot) to convey a "booked" state, which is not accessible for users who cannot perceive color differences.
complianceIssues.suggestedFix: Include a non-color cue such as a text label (e.g., "Booked") next to the dot or a distinct icon/shape. Ensure the label is present in the DOM for assistive technologies.

complianceIssues.issue: Form field borders are very low contrast against the white background, making input boundaries hard to discern.
White button text on the gold gradient background is unlikely to meet the 4.5:1 contrast ratio for normal-size text.
Gold text on a white (or light) background has insufficient contrast for normal text in outline buttons.
On hover, outline buttons switch to white text on a gold background, which may not meet the 4.5:1 contrast ratio.
